title: 104_s1549
content: The Act titled "Municipal Securities Investor Protection Act of 1996" is referred to as the short title. It addresses the treatment of municipal securities in the Securities Act of 1933. Section 3 of the Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include new provisions for municipal issuers seeking exemption from the Act. Municipal issuers must pledge full faith and credit or taxing power for timely payments, or meet specific criteria for aggregate principal amounts. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include provisions for municipal issuers seeking exemption. Municipal issuers must pledge full faith and credit or taxing power for timely payments, or meet specific criteria for aggregate principal amounts exceeding $1,000,000,000. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include provisions for municipal issuers seeking exemption, considering the public interest, investor protection, and prevention of circumvention of requirements. SEC. 3. Treatment of municipal securities in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions regarding securities issued by municipal issuers, specifying conditions for pledging full faith and credit or taxing power for timely payments. Securities can be offered or sold in transactions under $1,000,000,000 or in related series without reasonable restrictions. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions for securities issued by municipal issuers, specifying conditions for pledging full faith and credit or taxing power for timely payments. Securities can be offered or sold in transactions under $1,000,000,000 without restrictions. The term 'municipal issuer' is defined as a State, political subdivision, agency, instrumentality, or municipal corporate instrumentality of a State. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions for securities issued by municipal issuers, specifying conditions for pledging full faith and credit or taxing power for timely payments. The term 'municipal corporate instrumentality of a State' is defined, and the meaning of 'series of related transactions' and 'reasonably anticipate' is clarified by the Commission. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include provisions for municipal securities, specifying reporting requirements and exemptions for issuers. The duty to file may not be suspended based on the number of security holders. Reporting requirements prior to the sale of securities are also clarified for municipal issuers. The Trust Indenture Act of 1939 is amended to include provisions for municipal securities, specifying reporting requirements and exemptions for issuers. Section 304(a)(4) is amended to clarify subsection (a) and subsection (d) of section 3 of the Act.
